Roy McAvoy.Action: Stands confidently under bright lights hitting golf balls deep into the night with beer nearby, showing skilled focus and comfort in his environment.
Appears focused on a tough task (hitting golf balls at night) despite distractions like noise, drink, and others betting around him.
Leads the regulars inside to engage them with a riddle and encourages self-confidence.
Patiently explains that he already knows the answer to the riddle he poses to the group.
Engages the regulars with a riddle to stimulate their thinking and betting, showing confidence and control of the situation.
Challenges the players to demonstrate intelligence and pay attention, indirectly prompting active participation and engagement.
Engages others with a challenging riddle, offers to refund money if they disagree with his fairness.
Patiently responds to others' guesses and gently corrects misunderstandings.
Discreetly waves to the regulars to get lost while starting lesson with Molly.
Misses the ball he was bouncing after Molly questions him about feminism.
Responds humbly to Molly's feminist challenge without hostility.
Slightly condescending in teaching the lesson but accepts Molly’s wariness.
Calls Molly's golf training devices a 'waste of money' and '200 dollars of shit', showing irritation and impatience.
Despite irritation, stays engaged with Molly and hands her a driver to continue sharing his knowledge.
Recognizes and rejects ineffective golf gadgets and gimmicks brought by Molly, demonstrates practical insight into what helps actual golf performance.
Irritated and impatiently dismisses Molly's devices without attempting a more measured explanation, showing possible rigidity or impatience.
Uses humor and light teasing to encourage Molly during her first golf lesson.
Patiently demonstrates and explains golf swing to Molly with care and enthusiasm.
Invites Molly to use his first name, 'Call me Roy, Molly,' suggesting friendliness and lowering formal barriers.
Shares personal insight about his unfinished swing and admits to possibly never finishing anything, showing self-awareness and sincerity.
Engages in a poetic and thoughtful explanation of golf, demonstrating openness and a desire to connect meaningfully.
Describes his golf swing as a 'living sculpture' and acknowledges both its imperfections and strengths; shows deep awareness of his unique technique and its effectiveness.
Admits that his follow-through can look 'unfinished' and half-jokingly suggests it might reflect a personal flaw of never finishing anything.
Confidently instructs Molly on swinging the driver, uses humor and metaphors to teach, encourages relaxing rituals to improve play.
Observes Molly's poor shot but remains cheerful and positive, uses it as motivation rather than discouragement.
Successfully hits a perfect shot himself, demonstrating skill and confidence.
Responds to Molly's straightforward, judgment-free critique with self-deprecating humor and openness ('Perhaps I'm chocked full of inner demons?')
Shows sincere confusion and curiosity when asking Molly about being 'saddled,' engaging vulnerably in conversation
Welcomes regulars warmly and refers to Molly with playful respect and mild flirtation ('a class act there, boys; probably the first actual `lady type' female ever seen')
Operating a barely solvent establishment, ducking the I.R.S., collecting small amounts of money to buy beer despite being a 'legendary striker of the golf ball' capable of much more.
Responds to Molly's frank assessment with humor and openness, showing self-awareness and a willingness to engage thoughtfully.
Bets on multiple dogs including the underdog to get even with a friend rather than to win big.
Clarifies and corrects his own betting intentions when others misunderstand, emphasizing fairness rather than reckless risk.
Shows panic when realizing the high stakes of his wager, suggesting some vulnerability and sincerity.
Bets on all other dogs except the favorite to break even rather than to win big, showing cautious strategizing and risk management.
Panics when told he is risking twelve thousand dollars, indicating anxiety or stress under financial pressure.
Clarifies that he intended only to get even, not 'shoot the wad,' showing awareness and restraint in betting strategy.
Relies partly on a bet influenced by personal animosity (getting even with Doreen) rather than pure analysis, indicating some impulsiveness.
Lightly jokes about his romantic feelings to Romeo, attempting to lighten a tense moment.
Shows camaraderie and ease within a rougher social environment (strip joint), greeted warmly by various people.
Displays confidence despite financial trouble, indicating resilience rather than despair.
Shows confidence by telling Romeo 'You underestimate me' when discussing how to pay a large debt.
Acknowledges bankruptcy and losing everything, indicating failure or mismanagement.
Moves through a strip club environment with ease and grace, showing social skill and confidence in a challenging setting.
Greets the Naked Dancer warmly with a friendly 'Hiya, honey -- lookin' sweet...'
Displays familiarity and comfort entering Doreen's dressing room without hesitation or awkwardness
Engages respectfully with Doreen and seems willing to pay the debt owed, presenting official documents as proof of value
Enters backstage with complete familiarity despite being waved through by a bouncer, indicating confident, skilled navigation of social and physical space.
Tin Cup produces official-looking papers equating equity and inventory to twelve thousand dollars to pay Doreen, showing resourcefulness and knowledge in handling a debt situation.
Offers equity, inventory, and cash flow of driving range to settle a debt, showing willingness to find a fair solution.
Pays his employees modest wages (tractor kid $5/hr, Romeo $10/hr cash).
Remains silent and non-defensive when accused by Doreen about taking money and goods unethically.
Hocks golf clubs to manage financial hardship rather than ask for help.
Asks Romeo to tell visitors he is busy to avoid interaction.
Implicitly shows reluctance to engage with others, reflecting guardedness.
Hocks his golf clubs to pay off debt, showing financial struggle and poor management of his livelihood.
Attempts to downplay troubles and maintain confidence by pretending to be 'on business in Houston' to avoid confrontation.
Receives an invitation from a successful rival to join a big charity event, indicating recognition of his skill despite personal setbacks.
Fondly recalls and praises an old teammate from university, showing appreciation for past camaraderie.
Initially responds warily to Simms's proposition but then enthusiastically accepts, pumping Simms’s hand and expressing excitement.
Responds with a teasing remark ('Then make more birdies.') when Simms explains his proposal, showing friendly banter rather than hostility.
Upon learning Simms only wants him to caddie rather than play together, visibly wilts, indicating wounded pride but no hostility toward Simms.
Simms acknowledges Roy as a great ball-striker and a skilled golfer familiar with the course.
Roy initially reacts warily and with some skepticism to Simms's offer but eventually agrees enthusiastically, showing confidence and readiness.
Roy's enthusiasm fades when he learns he is to be a caddie rather than a player, indicating possible discomfort or reduced confidence in that role.
Agrees to caddie for Simms despite feeling humiliated and despite the cynical reason for the offer.
Expresses disdain for Simms, describing him as everything he hates in life.
Accepts a caddie job for a big-time corporate sponsored tournament despite feeling humiliated and out of place.
Feels humiliated and struggles to assert himself verbally in front of Simms, showing insecurity.
Offers to hit a difficult shot over water when asked if he can make it.
Encourages Simms to play aggressively for the gallery instead of playing it safe.
Makes a witty comment about earning a five percent cut to ease tension.
Confidently offers to hit a difficult 215-yard carry over water that others doubt.
Encourages Simms to take a risky shot rather than playing it safe.
Understands the role of a caddy to support the player and helps Simms try to win, showing grasp of the game situation.
Clamps a hand over Simms' club to challenge him to hit the difficult shot, shows confrontational behavior.

Clamps hand over opponent's club, urging him to take a riskier shot, showing confidence and willingness to confront.
Mocks Simms' conservative choice, demonstrating knowledge about the game and strategic boldness.
Mutters sarcastic commentary to the gallery, showing insight into audience expectations and mental gamesmanship.
Engages in hostile banter with Simms, risking escalation and potential negative consequences for teamwork.
Puts down Simms's golf bag to accept the challenge despite the risk to his job.
Responds to Simms's threat about being fired with a good-natured, lightly teasing comment about the firing happening in front of everyone only if he makes the shot.
Considers a high-risk shot from a difficult lie on national TV under pressure, showing confidence and willingness to take on challenges.
Responds to the threat of being fired by asserting confidence in his ability to succeed in front of a large audience.
Hits an excellent shot under pressure, eliciting crowd cheers.
Argues with David Simms and resists giving up the golf bag after being told the loop is over.
Goes berserk wrestling with marshals and replacement caddie, causing a public spectacle.
Drinks cheap whiskey and Maalox alone in back room, reflects on his shot with persistence.
Engages in a candid conversation with Romeo without hostility, showing vulnerability.
Goes berserk and wrestles with marshals after losing his composure
Swigs cheap whiskey and Maalox after the incident, indicating poor self-management
Despite failure and embarrassment, reflects on choice to hit a risky shot and stands by it
Shows stubborn determination to beat a rival by taking a difficult approach
Holds up papers to support Doreen during her dance, showing active encouragement.
Offers Doreen his tournament winnings as a business proposition, trying to negotiate to get his driving range back.
Chases after Doreen with beer and entry forms while trying to persuade her.
Refuses to punch in time on a time clock, expressing resentment at being treated like a working stiff.
Offers to trade his potential tournament winnings as a business proposition to reclaim his driving range, showing initiative and confidence in his golfing skill and financial negotiation.
Insists on not punching a time clock, expressing disdain for routine work structure, indicating resistance to conventional discipline.
Tees a ball for Molly and gently offers her golf advice with encouragement to show 'warmth and compassion' to the club.
Moves around to reposition Molly's shoulders and places his hands discreetly and professionally to square her hips while coaching her.
Asks Molly about her personal life subtly while enhancing her technical golf skills.
Teaches Molly golf technique carefully and tries to improve her stance and swing with patience and subtle adjustments.
Is aware of the importance of touch and trust in golf instruction, showing an understanding beyond just mechanics.
Attempts to engage Molly personally while professionally helping her, indicating social awareness and multitasking ability.

Expresses insecurity and self-doubt about his life and worthiness.
Reflects deeply and sincerely on his situation and desire to improve for the sake of others.
Reflects deeply on his personal shortcomings and motivation to rise to a higher level worthy of respect.

Struggles with feelings of crushing self-doubt and views himself as a loser.

Dismisses Romeo's warnings and criticism about his game and finances, showing stubbornness and refusal to listen.

Successfully executes a difficult shot with skill but without gloating; offers to finish the hole.

Hits an impossible bunker shot with ease and facility, then sinks the putt for par.
Calls his shot accurately, demonstrating awareness of the course and conditions.
Feels slightly cornered but tries to avoid making his romantic life an issue, shows focus on his quest.

Uses crude humor and physical gestures when embarrassed during conversation with Romeo.
Expresses determination to focus on qualifying for The Open despite personal distractions.

Clearly articulates his motivations and personal quest, demonstrating self-awareness and confidence.
Grabs himself in public, making a fool of himself, then shows embarrassment and chagrin.

Points shot confidently despite difficult position in rough.
Attempts a difficult shot from the deep rough, but the ball only weakly comes out and lands near a tree, resulting in a worse score.
Responds confidently and with determination to competitor Simms, asserting he will 'own' him despite setbacks.
Drains a putt to improve his score.
Puts a firmly-struck putt that just misses, causing audience groans.
Responds confidently and enjoys the challenge when taunted by a competitor.
Whispers to Romeo about not catching all of Simms' shot before teeing up himself, showing a quiet moment of communication and possible consideration.
Focused on his own shot and competition, no overt interaction with others here, maintaining concentration.
Hits a perfect drive down the middle of the fairway during a critical moment, showcasing skill and confidence.
Experts express concern about his inexperience leading him to take risky shots, implying potential overconfidence or lack of strategic caution.
Seeks out Molly's face in the crowd and speaks to her quietly about the importance of the moment.
Whispers criticism about Simms as a 'gutless wonder' for laying up instead of taking a more aggressive shot.
Chooses to go for an eagle shot on the final hole despite the safer option to lay up for birdie.
Decides to go for a risky shot despite others advising him to play safe.
Selects the three wood and attempts a high-risk shot to go for the green under challenging conditions.
Fails to account adequately for environmental factors (wind), leading to the ball landing in the water despite technical skill.
Insists on playing a risky shot from original lie instead of taking the safer drop suggested by others.
After the failed shot, calmly holds out his hand to Romeo asking for another ball despite the crowd’s uncomfortable reaction.
Rejects taking the safe drop to save par and force a playoff, insisting he can make a difficult shot from a risky lie.
Confidently swings again, hitting a long and true shot.
Despite confidence and skillful execution, his risky shot ends up in the water, resulting in failure.
Keeps trying to prove a point despite the risk and others' concerns, shows determination without complaint.
Holds out his hand quietly for another ball each time he fails, accepting help without fuss.
Insists he can make it across despite repeated failures that could disqualify him.
Keeps trying to make a difficult shot despite repeated failures and mounting pressure, insists he can make it across the water hazard.
Fails to successfully complete the shot multiple times, ultimately risks disqualification by continuing to attempt the impossible.
Raises his three wood aloft in triumph, looks at Molly and cracks a smile; takes his hat off and walks to the green to acknowledge the ovation.
Brusquely moves past Simms after a witty exchange but still congratulates Tubbs, the winner, as he passes.
Successfully makes a very difficult shot clearing the water hazard and sinking the ball in the hole, triggering a huge crowd reaction.
Maintains focus and composure on a challenging shot, setting his jaw and concentrating despite earlier failed attempts.
Walks away from second place finish somewhat brusquely, acknowledging the winner and showing sportsmanship.
Embraces Molly openly after his failure, admits his mistake sincerely and calls himself a fool.
Receives support and encouragement from regulars who remain loyal after his poor performance.
Hits a disastrous twelve on the last hole of the U.S. Open, despite knowing that laying up was the smarter play.
Acknowledges his own mistake aloud and accepts responsibility for giving away the Open.
Despite his failure, demonstrates confidence and skill earlier that brought admiration from others.
Allows Molly to rest her head on his shoulder, sharing a peaceful moment together.
Engages in a sincere and reflective conversation with Molly, showing vulnerability about what he learned from his experiences.
Expresses concern that going back to Qualifying School would mean not seeing Molly, indicating care for their relationship.
Doesn't know he qualified for the Open by finishing top 15, showing some lack of awareness about the tour's rules.
Openly reflects on his past experiences, tries to learn from them and consider lessons about discipline, self-control, and caution.
Expresses hesitation about going back to Qualifying School because it might reduce personal time and connections, showing insight and prioritization.
